children.content: I'm also one of the hosts of the Reason Town podcast, which you should check out if you want to learn more about reason & its community.
We have a large frontend web app that's been using React ever since it was open sourced 5 years ago, and iOS & Android native apps to which we added React Native 1 year ago.
We still have substantial native swift & java code, but we're moving more of the UI over to React Native all the time.
We also integrated GraphQL & Apollo last year, and are slowly moving our data concerns over to it.
Hi! I'm Jared Forsyth, and I do mobile & web development at Khan Academy, where we're building a free, world-class education for anyone, anywhere.
Much of what I'm going to say here applies to both React & React native, and some of it
My goal: get you all to try out Reason ðŸ˜ƒ
who has written any reason or ocaml?
another thing that's not captured here is that flow & typescript are evolving quite rapidly... which is not exactly what you want in a type system.
Based on a battle-tested type system
It's a ton better than using plain old javascript, but there are a couple of key differences that make me excited about using Reason in this context.
In our react-native codebase at khan academy, we're using flow all the way.
How does Reason compare to Flow/TypeScript?
pattern matching w/ warning if you didn't handle, type error if you try to handle more
but they result in type errors like this:
and really, there's not much you can do about it!
structural types make a ton of sense if you're bolting a type system on top of a loosey-goosey language like javascript.
Nominal types are faster to compile & give better type errors
because the type system is stricter, you actually can get a ton more inference -- such that I rarely annotate function declarations!
How does Reason compare to Flow/TypeScript?
Talk about stability of the type system!!!!!!
whether this is react on the web, or react-native -- reason is the best way to write it.
Reason is the best way to write React
I should replace the "search" bar with just "docs", and it's a TOC of the bundled libraries n stuff
(have an autoplay mp4 that I can talk over)
I recently made a new online playground with a bunch of fancy features -- you can try it inline, make react components, etc. It comes bundled with a couple of libraries, but could support more

!a ```
$ $1npm i bs-platform bs-react-native reason-react$

$ cat > $2bsconfig.json$
{"name":"my-project","refmt":3,"sources":"src",
 "bs-dependencies": ["bs-react-native", "reason-react"],
 "reason": {"react-jsx": true},
 "package-specs": {"module": "commonjs", "in-source": true}}

$ $3./node_modules/.bin/bsb -make-world$
```
Adding it to a current react-native project
ummm maybe I need to showcase reducers as well. although it could go in key differences?
A huge emphasis of the reason project
Now I'm going to go over some things that might trip you up when you're starting out.

you might be mad about this, I super didn't like it when I first started out. I'm less sad now, but I think it might make sense to move to a java-style setup, where you have to declare your imports at the top, but they're managed for you automatically by the IDE.
No require()s. All files in your project are just available to you.

```
let x = a => b() + 2; /* won't compile */
let b = () => 5;
let x = a => b() + 2; /* this is fine */
```
Ways that JavaScript is still better
One of the things I'm excited about is reason-apollo -- because you get the full backing of a type system!! It's so good
here's a project that I think is going to be as big a deal for reason as react-native was for react.
